title: Chicago cop Jason Van Dyke officially resigns, while serving prison time for killing Laquan McDonald
text:
Jason Van Dyke, imprisoned for killing Laquan McDonald in 2014, has formally left the Chicago Police Department.

Van Dyke, who is serving a nearly seven-year sentence for the fatal shooting of the 17-year old, resigned last week.

The jury found him guilty last October on one count of second-degree murder and 16 counts of aggravated battery — one for each bullet that hit McDonald’s body.

Police Superintendent Eddie Johnson filed for Van Dyke’s dismissal this summer on the grounds that his state certification to act as a law enforcement officer had been revoked following his felony conviction, the Chicago Tribune reported.

Jason Van Dyke is officially out at the Chicago Police Department. The former officer is serving a prison term for killing Laquan McDonald in 2014

Laquan McDonald at his graduation. He was killed by Chicago police officer Jason Van Dyke, who resigned from the department

Jason Van Dyke at his sentencing hearing in January. He was convicted in the shooting death of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald

When Van Dyke's trial concluded last fall, he made dubious history as the first Chicago cop in a half-century to be convicted of murder for an on-duty incident.

The department moved to dismiss him in 2014 but was placed on hold while his criminal case was pending in 2015.

Max Caproni of the Chicago Police Board says Van Dyke's attorneys informed the board of his resignation and that he won't collect a pension, NBC5 reported.

Van Dyke shot and killed the teen, who was high on PCP and refused orders to drop a knife while walking away.

Jason Van Dyke (right) holds his baby at 2002 academy graduation. The cop is serving a prison sentence for second-degree murder and aggravated battery

Jason Van Dyke, serving prison time for murder, officially resigned from the Chicago Police Department

Jason Van Dyke being led away after a conviction at his murder trial in Oct. 2018

Dashcam video of the shooting was released by a judge more than a year later causing more tension between minority communities and police.

The dissension led to an internal investigation by the city Inspector General Joseph Ferguson's office, who recommended that 11 police officers-- including Van Dyke-- be fired. However, six of them, including two high-ranking officials on the scene in 2014, resigned before any punishment could be handled down.

In addition to the Van Dyke trial, three other officers were charged with trying to cover for Van Dyke by exaggerating the threat by McDonald, the Tribune reported.

Van Dyke, 41, is serving his sentence in a medium-security federal prison in Otisville, N.Y., an hour north of New York City. He's scheduled to be released in February 2022.
description: Jason Van Dyke resigned from the Chicago Police Department. The police superintendent filed for Van Dyke's dismissal that his state certification as a police officer was revoked with the conviction.
